title: No. 20 Cal takes on UCLA in an ESPN game Thursday
text:
No. 20 Cal takes on UCLA in an ESPN game Thursday By Jeff Faraudo Posted: 10/21/2015 10:29:52 AM PDT Updated: 10/21/2015 07:18:30 PM PDT PASADENA -- Twelve days later, 20th-ranked Cal takes the big stage again Thursday night, facing UCLA in an ESPN national broadcast from the Rose Bowl. 
So, the entire Bay Area will be watching? 
Maybe not. The 49ers are playing the Seattle Seahawks at the same time. And the NBA champion Warriors and the Sharks also have TV games Thursday night. 
Cal receiver Stephen Anderson sees reasons to be optimistic. 
"The Giants aren't in the playoffs -- that's a big thing," he said. "I know the Niners are playing, but the Niners are having a bad year. I like our chances of getting a good amount of viewers." California head coach Sonny Dykes reacts to a call by officials during the first half an NCAA college football game against Washington, Saturday, Sept. 26, 2015, in Seattle. Cal won 30-24. (AP Photo/Elaine Thompson) ( Elaine Thompson ) 
Whichever portion of the TV audience the Bears draw, they expect to be more comfortable with the bright lights than in their last game, when six turnovers sabotaged an otherwise solid effort in a 30-24 road loss to unbeaten Utah. 
"I feel like there was a lot of buildup for that game -- two undefeated teams," Cal coach Sonny Dykes said. "It was the first time since I was here our program has gotten that type of exposure. I don't feel like we responded to it that well. 
"I think our guys will handle this better. At least I hope they will." 
This is a big game for Cal (5-1, 2-1 Pac-12), which needs one more victory to become bowl eligible and seeks a win in Southern California for the first time since 2009. The Bruins (4-2, 1-2) are coming off defeats to Stanford and Arizona State by a combined margin of 36 points and will be desperate for a change of fortune. Advertisement 
Cal faced a similar scenario a year ago, opening with a 4-1 record before slamming into the challenging portion of its schedule and losing all momentum. The Bears wound up 5-7 and out of the bowl picture. 
Dykes believes this team -- older, deeper and far better on defense -- is ready to alter the script. 
"Part of our maturation as a football program," Dykes said, "is just believing we're good enough to win against good football teams on the road, especially when you don't play well." 
The bye week should benefit Cal. While UCLA was pounded last Thursday night at Stanford, the Bears had the chance to heal physically and emotionally after letting go a game they could have won. 
Quarterback Jared Goff, who slipped out of the Heisman Trophy conversation after a five-interception performance at Utah, said he learned from his mistakes and has moved on. Offensive coordinator Tony Franklin made sure Goff understood he wasn't the first elite quarterback to have a rough outing. 
"I told him (Peyton) Manning threw six picks in a game. Brett Favre threw six picks in a game," Franklin said. "The shame of it was it was a game we could have won if he has a good ballgame. But that's part of it. He's got to overcome it, and he will." 
UCLA coach Jim Mora is expecting Goff's best effort. 
"Goff is pretty darn special," Mora said. "He has that mindset that all great quarterbacks have in that they're able to put a bad play behind them and keep going. 
"As an observer of football, it's been fun to watch him develop. As somebody who has to play him, it's not that fun." 
Dykes is encouraged by the fact that his team -- two years removed from a 1-11 season -- has posted five victories but still has room for growth. He's also a bit antsy to see it happen. 
"I don't feel like we've played a complete game, where we've put it all together -- offense, defense and special teams," he said. "We better start doing it pretty soon. We better do it Thursday."
